background.global_rank: third most common malignancy in women worldwide

epidemiologic_trend_us.trend: declined steadily over past few decades
epidemiologic_trend_us.screening_effect: detection and treatment of preinvasive disease

screening_recommendation.evaluation_method: colposcopy and biopsy for symptoms, abnormal screening results, or gross cervical lesion

treatment_by_stage.disseminated_disease: chemotherapy or radiation for symptom palliation

overview.definition: cancerous tissue forms on the surface of the cervix

types.prevalence: combination of squamous cell carcinomas and adenocarcinomas

pathophysiology.hpv_requirement: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection required for cervical cancer

hpv_infection_stats.clearance_rate: 90% clear within months to a few years
hpv_infection_stats.cytology_post_infection: may show low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion within 2 years

progression_stats.cin_2_3_development: 5% of HPV infections develop CIN grade 2 or 3 within 3 years
progression_stats.cin_3_to_cancer_5_years: 20% of CIN 3 lesions progress to invasive cervical cancer within 5 years
progression_stats.cin_3_to_cancer_30_years: 40% of CIN 3 lesions progress to invasive cervical cancer within 30 years

carcinogenesis_factors.details: high-risk HPV types and persistent infection increase progression risk; low-risk HPV types do not cause cervical cancer
poor nutritional status, immunocompromise, HIV infection
early age of first intercourse, higher number of sexual partners
use for 5+ years associated with increased risk, possibly due to higher HPV infection risk or direct interaction

genetic_susceptibility.relative_risk: 2-fold for women with affected first-degree biologic relative

associated_genes.effect: polymorphisms associated with increased HPV infection progression to cervical cancer
some anomalies increase risk, others protective
may influence susceptibility by disrupting immune response to HPV
may influence susceptibility by disrupting immune response to HPV
polymorphism in promoter region associated with decreased risk

epigenetic_modifications.role: aberrant DNA methylation patterns associated with cervical cancer development

mechanism.integration: E6 and E7 genes enhanced replication
mechanism.result: resistance to apoptosis, uncensored cell growth, progression to malignancy

hiv_interaction.prevalence: at least 5 times more common in HIV-infected women

global_stats.rank: third most common malignancy in women
global_stats.developing_countries: second most common cancer, second most common cause of cancer-related deaths
global_stats.developed_countries: tenth most common cancer, not in top 10 causes of cancer deaths

us_stats.incidence_trend: decreased by 2.1% per year (women <50), 3.1% per year (women ≥50) since 2004

stage_1_symptoms: watery or bloody vaginal discharge, possibly heavy and foul-smelling
vaginal bleeding after sex, between periods, or after menopause
advanced_symptoms: difficult or painful urination, sometimes with blood
fatigue, weight loss, loss of appetite

hpv_role.causation: causes almost all cervical cancer cases
hpv_role.vaccine_efficacy: protects against HPV strains causing up to 90% of cervical cancers

symptoms_and_causes.progression_timeline: 3-7 years for precancerous changes to become cancer
complications: bladder and bowel issues (difficulty urinating, constipation)
blood clots due to increased blood viscosity
bleeding from vagina, rectum, or bladder
treatment side effects (nausea, fatigue, sexual dysfunction)

screening.follow_up: HPV test for abnormal Pap results

diagnostic_tests.description: magnifies cervical cells to identify irregularities
uses cutting tool to remove precancerous cells
uses electrical wire loop to remove abnormal tissue
removes cone-shaped piece of cervical tissue

stages.description: cancer confined to cervix neck, not in deeper tissues
cancer spread beyond cervix and uterus, not to pelvic wall or lower vagina
cancer spread to lower vagina, possibly pelvic wall, ureters, or lymph nodes
cancer spread to bladder, rectum, or distant organs (bones, lungs)

methods.description: radiation placed in or near cancer

treatment_options.description: drugs injected or taken orally, given in cycles

methods.description: removes cervix and upper vagina, preserves uterus
removes uterus, cervix, bladder, vagina, rectum, part of colon

treatment_options.description: destroys specific cancer cells by targeting growth proteins
stimulates immune system to recognize and destroy cancer cells
diet, herbs, acupuncture; consult provider for safety

cure_potential.general: highly treatable, especially in early stages
cure_potential.stage_4: cure unlikely, remission possible with radiation, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

prognosis.outlook: highly treatable in early stages, requires close monitoring post-treatment

methods: regular gynecological exams and Pap tests

when_to_contact_provider: bleeding between periods or after menopause
pelvic pain or pain during sex
living_with_cervical_cancer.emotional_support: discuss diagnosis and treatment with healthcare team, consider counseling
